ygData.subject: Re: Tic-Tac-Toe Experiment Update
ygData.msgSnippet: Coevolution is a an extremely complex problem.  There is a lot of work right now going into ways to make sure progress is real progress and not just going in

Subject: Re: Tic-Tac-Toe Experiment Update
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=DfvWqXbk_GEeD61IJ3KFGiZiU6Tdz9GJGyl72R4EW0DHyU9PGvYH
X-Yahoo-Profile: kenstanley01

Coevolution is a an extremely complex problem.  There is a lot of 
work right now going into ways to make sure progress is real 
progress and not just going in circles or going off in bizarre 
tangents in the strategy space.  This problem seems likely to happen 
in board games where the initial strategies will be quite alien, so 
the improvements you get will be geared toward beating aliens.  It 
seems less of a problem in for example control domains like Robot 
Duel where it's hard to really have an "alien" strategy.  In any 
case, the mathematics behind tracking progress or ensuring progress 
have to do with game theory and Pareto optimality, and were 
discussed extensively at the Coevolution workshop this year at GECCO 
(where I was on the panel).  I would suggest reading papers by Edwin 
De Jong, Sevan Ficici, and Anthony Bucci.  Paul Wiegand also has a 
lot of cooperative coevolution issues.  Anyway, these guys (most 
alumni of the DEMO lab at Brandeis) are really moving towards 
theoretically founded theory of coevolution, which is quite 
interesting and deep.

On the other hand, none of their stuff says anything about 
representation, which is where NEAT comes in.  The complexification 
of the genome seems to go hand in hand with the coevolutionary 
dynamic.  But it is not necessarily enough to know whether progress 
is really happening or not.  That requires some kind of theory of 
progress.  Note a lot of progress has been made in this area in the 
last few years, so it's no longer just speculative.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> 
> This graph:
> 
> 
http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/tmp/TicTacToe_SimpleDominanceChain.pn
g
> 
> shows progress so far using evaluation against a dominance chain. 
(BTW 
> it's worth noting the sudden jump in fitness in the center of the 
graph, 
> just after a pruning phase has started)
> 
> Fitness against a random player has actually fallen slightly today 
and 
> with the graph plateuing out to some degree I think this 
demonstrates 
> that this specific experiment isn't working that well, especially 
if we 
> factor in that the graph shows fitness vs generations - and that 
the 
> search speed has now dropped off considerably.
> 
> So more work required, but an interesting first stab at co-ev 
> Tic-Tac-Toe with NEAT.
> 
> Colin
